comments.commentBody:
In December, Obama ordered an investigation of Russian interference with the November election. Under the law, to place a wiretap, the FBI would have had to:present to a judge specific evidence of a suspected crime. In this case, it was known that the Russians had hacked Hillary's emails, that Trump had denied it and defended the Russians, that the Russians had hacked Trump, but did nothing with what they learned, that Trump people had contacts with the Russians, and that the Russians much preferred Trump's elections to Hillary's. That is ample evidence of probable cause, which is not to say that the Trump people committed crimes, only that there was enough there to conclude that it was probable.

Because the content of private conversations were the only definitive evidence of any criminal activity, a wiretap would surely have been authorized by a judge. Hillary people should not jump to conclusions -- many wiretaps turn up nothing and all the smoke is just smoke. Moreover, if there were wiretaps, that's proof positive that Comey was not sabotaging Hillary,

As for Obama people, they should rest assured that if their man sought wiretaps, he was acting well within the law.

They could forget to bring him back from his weekends at Mar-a-Lago -- in five weeks, four weekends down there at taxpayer expense (some $10 million).  He likes it so much, he should stay there.  People could call it a silly name -- such as the "Winter White House" even though it's a resort that people pay to stay in.  That would convince him he's still president working on mass deportations, signing executive orders all day long, etc.  They could assure him that all is going as planned.
Can't wait to watch the Sunday morning news roundtables tomorrow! It will be almost as good as Saturday Night Live!
my god, when is this going to come to an end?  follow the money to cyprus.

Whether a FISA court approval to wiretap President Trump's phone in Trump Tower has or has not occurred, it is clear that either result is an issue that equal or exceeds Watergate. A FISA court approval of a wiretap implies there was something to investigate. If there wasn't FISA court approval, violations of law again equal or exceed Watergate.

There is also one other possibility, if President Trump either made this outlandish rant up himself or relied on the right wing media and bogus reporting means the US has a President that is impulsive, dangerous and unhinged. The scary aspect of these characteristics is that the President is the one who controls the nuclear codes.

The Republican Congress and the Cabinet really need to be discussing when and whether to invoke Section 4 of the 25th Amendment of the Constitution.

I'm starting to think that whenever the media veer off to give someone or something else a headline (Sessions, North Korea, the Oscars, et al), Trump starts feeling left out, and turns back into a tweeting troll all over again.
And how can his "Base" defend this?
His base hates Obama.
Easily!  They detest Obama.

Given the Russiaghazi scandals, of which the end is not in sight, and given that our "president" is propagating theories with no evidence whatsoever, and what appears to be an administration adrift in a heavy sea, will someone in Congressional GOP leadership (must exhibit sanity and intelligence and love of the country over party) declare that Trump is unfit for office?
Many of us remember the dark days of another deluded President and he graced us with his resignation, the antics and demonstrations of late with this very young and disjointed administration is unnerving and is further fracturing this country. Perhaps Trump should follow Nixon's footsteps.
I cannot recall so many early crisis in a Presidential administration as this.
We the people, Trump supporters or not, expect an effective administration, not one hobbled by scandal after scandal, conspiracy theories and ethical questions.
The emperor has proven beyond a doubt he has no clothes.
where's the rule about presidents impugning presidents?

Trump's shocking accusation that the Trump Tower phones were tapped requires a special prosecutor, and then some. The presence of wire taps would indicate that the Justice Department suspected that either criminal activity was taking place or that Trump and his associates were acting as foreign agents. However, Trump's accusation that President Obama ordered the wire taps is clearly a case of defamation per se. Trump is accusing the former president of breaking the law. The right-wing bloggers involved in disseminating this lie, are guilty of defamation per se. So, there are elements of his accusation that pertain to criminal activity, defamation, national security and the insinuation of a government cover up. The complexity of his lies is breathtaking.
did not pres  reagan relate stories as real which were only the plots of movies he appeared in ?
I think you are right.

Simply because, for the first time in his public life Trump gave a speech without lying or throwing out baseless or contradictory flash bangs only proves he can read a teleprompter speech written by someone else.

Sessions Controversy Heightens Trump’s Feeling of Being Under Siege - sad.
As his behavior get worse and worse it's obvious that he really can't stand the pressure. He should step down or be forced out.

Probable cause for warrant puts Trump on defensive.
No warrant starts investigation by Congress into false accusations made by a sitting POTUS about a former POTUS.
Lose/Lose for Trump--this time he went too far.
Obama hasn't said that wiretapping never happened, rather insisted that he didn't order it.
Oh, it happened. But you are right, it was not Obama.
He has achieved a new low. I didn't think it possible.
You ain't seen nothing yet.

So if FISA were around for Nixon to use and they approved his warrant requests, then Nixon's taping activities would be A-OK?

Once upon a time being a Liberal meant you were AGAINST secret courts with 99% warrant approval statistics.
It seems the only real evidence Trump ever offers is related to the confirmation of his mental illness..
Wish I could recomend this 1000 times, V.  The shallow, fawning and seemingly dimwitted talking heads on the cable news networks don't need much to be impressed, that's for sure.

If this were true, a rational person would collect evidence, develop a plan, mobilize their resources for further action to address the issue before going public.  But Trump is not rational, and there is nothing provided to suggest that these accusations are anything more than paranoid ravings.  The state of the presidency and the total willingness of the republican party to remain silent and accept this man as their representative is mind-boggling.

I think he has no judgment. He has never had to answer to anyone and seriously believes that what he says is the truth. He is now an employee and can't understand his responsibilities or the law to which he is answerable.

It's now no longer a question of how low Trump will go, but rather, how long will he last. One gets the impression that he's been installed as a puppet by the GOP willingly supported by the Russians, but even that doesn't seen outlandish enough to come near what is true.

The guy has form, bad form, and it is a measure of the depths of division that fracture America that someone so unsuited to the office of President now sits, however uneasily, atop the highest office in the land, and perhaps, the world.

Has he irrevocably tainted the office? Probably not, after all, it's not the position that is the problem, it's, in this case, the man.

The bigger problem that requires solution, is to strengthen democracy so that a Trump like character doesn't stand a chance, but even then, specific rules will always have their weak spots.

If we truly believe in a democracy, then the responsibility falls on the people, after all, they voted him in, or as the case may be, didn't vote at all. Trump presents us with a cautionary tale of how poor judgement leads one astray. If we're willing to give him as pass, as we do with most politicians, then surely it's childish to complain. If, instead, he is no more than a distorted reflection of American society, then sit back and enjoy the ride.

Article four of the twenty-fifth amendment provides for removal from office for a president deemed to be unable to fulfill his duties by the vice-president and a majority of the executives (cabinet etc). But then 2/3 of the House and Senate have to vote in support of removal. Good luck with this congress.
Then go on Netflix and check out "A Face in the Crowd"!
